_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

UAP Distribution Inc.
West of Seguin
Seguin, KS



Updated new required RMP information. As of 2-9-2006, UAP Distribution, Inc. is the owner of this facility. Mr. Dan Niblock will act as the emergency contact and is the operations manager of this facility.

For more information regarding this plan, contact Kevin O?Rourke, ERS Manager, 7251 W. 4th Street, Greeley, Colorado 80634 (970) 347-1716, or Dan Niblock, UAP, 3 miles West Highway 24, Hoxie, KS (785)675-3354.

Risk Management Plan ? Executive Summary

1. The facility Policy

A) The owners, management and employees of UAP Distribution, Inc, are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department and other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility information

A) This facility has been owned and operated by UAP Distribution, Inc. since February, 2006. The maximum quantity stored would be approximately 106,000 pounds based on filling storage and nurse tanks to the designed capacity of 85%.

B) The primary activity of this facility, as it related to anhydrous ammonia, is the storage and transfer of anhydrous ammonia to farmers s a crop nutrient.

3. The Worst-Case and Alternate-Case Release Scenarios

A) The Worst-case scenario is based on the entire contents of the storage tanks being released over a 10 minute period. The quantity released would equal approximately 53,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, which represents the volume of the largest tank filled to 85% capacity as limited by design standards. The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion at 200 ppm) is 1.1 miles.

B) The alternate-case scenario is based on a release caused by a break in a transfer hose. The quantity release would be approximately 12,000. The distance to endpoint is 0.56 miles.
The Accidental Release Prevention Program

A) This facility has implemented the provisions of ANSI publication K-61.1, ?Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.?

B) This facility is in compliance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.111, ?Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.?

C) This facility follows the Anhydrous Ammonia Standards enforced by the Kansas Department of Agriculture, and is inspected by them on a regular basis.

D) This facility is inspected on at least a monthly basis by employees knowledgeable in the safe handling of anhydrous ammonia.

5. The Five-Year Accident History

A) There have been no accidents in the previous five years involving the release of anhydrous ammonia at this facility, including the time while operated as Sunflower Chemical, Inc.

6. The Emergency Response Program

A) This facility has an emergency response plan in accordance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38.

B) This facility has provided State and Local Agencies the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA.)

C) This facility has written emergency response plan in accordance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.120.

7. Planned Changes to improve Safety

Safety improvement is an on-going process at this faculty. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance pf safety conditions, as well as to evaluate employee safety training programs. There are no specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations or improvements to be made at this time.
